title: 108_s553
content: The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to offer interest-bearing transaction accounts with up to 24 transfers per month. Additionally, the Act authorizes the payment of interest on reserves at Federal Reserve Banks. The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" permits depository institutions to provide interest-bearing transaction accounts with a limit of 24 transfers monthly. It also authorizes the payment of interest on reserves held at Federal Reserve Banks. The amendment to the Federal Reserve Act allows balances held by depository institutions at a Federal Reserve Bank to earn interest quarterly at rates not exceeding short-term interest rates. The Board may establish regulations on the payment and distribution of these earnings to the maintaining depository institutions. The paragraph discusses the responsibilities of depository institutions, Federal home loan banks, and the National Credit Union Administration Central Liquidity Facility regarding the crediting and distribution of earnings from balances maintained at a Federal Reserve Bank. The term 'depository institution' includes trust companies and corporations organized under specific sections. The text discusses amendments to the Federal Reserve Act, including the definition of 'institution' and authorization for pass-through reserves for member banks. Technical and conforming amendments are also outlined. SEC. 4 amends the Federal Reserve Act to increase flexibility in setting reserve requirements. The ratio can now be not greater than 3 percent (including zero) and not less than zero. SEC. 5 discusses the transfer of Federal Reserve surpluses. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to require additional transfers from surplus funds to cover interest payments for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. The Federal Reserve banks will transfer necessary sums to the Board for deposit in the Treasury's general fund, with the allocation determined by the Federal Reserve Board. During fiscal years 2003 through 2007, Federal Reserve banks must transfer excess amounts from their surplus funds to cover interest payments. Any surplus funds exceeding 3 percent of paid-in capital and surplus of member banks will be transferred to the Treasury's general fund.
